content.title: Acute Kidney Injury
content.summary: Rapid decline in kidney function over hours to days, defined by rise in serum creatinine and/or decrease in urine output, staged using KDIGO criteria
key_points: KDIGO definition: Cr rise ≥0.3 mg/dL in 48h, or ≥1.5× baseline in 7 days, or UOP <0.5 mL/kg/h for 6h
Three categories: Pre-renal (hypoperfusion), Intrinsic (parenchymal damage), Post-renal (obstruction)
Pre-renal is most common (40-70%); responds to volume resuscitation
FENa <1% suggests pre-renal; >2% suggests ATN (intrinsic); unreliable with diuretics
Urinalysis: Muddy brown casts = ATN; RBC casts = glomerulonephritis; WBC casts = interstitial nephritis
Prevention is key: Avoid nephrotoxins, maintain euvolemia, contrast precautions in high-risk patients
AKI increases risk of CKD, ESRD, cardiovascular events, and mortality
content.statement: Acute Kidney Injury (AKI) is a clinical syndrome characterized by rapid decline in kidney function, diagnosed by standardized KDIGO criteria based on serum creatinine changes and/or urine output, requiring systematic evaluation to identify etiology and guide management.

explanation.intuition: Think of AKI as the kidney losing its filtering capacity suddenly. The body accumulates waste products (creatinine, urea), fluid, and electrolyte imbalances that would normally be excreted. Finding the cause determines whether this is reversible.
explanation.key_insight: The key to AKI evaluation is categorization: Pre-renal (not enough blood flow to kidneys), Intrinsic (damage to kidney tissue itself), or Post-renal (blockage of urine outflow). Each has different treatment - pre-renal needs volume, intrinsic needs supportive care, post-renal needs obstruction relief.
explanation.technical_details: GFR falls when fewer nephrons are functioning or when hemodynamic changes reduce filtration pressure. Serum creatinine rises as generation exceeds excretion. The lag between injury and creatinine rise (12-24 hours) means creatinine underestimates early AKI. Novel biomarkers (NGAL, KIM-1) may detect injury earlier but aren't yet standard of care.

definitions_glossary.acute_kidney_injury: Sudden decline in kidney function with rise in creatinine and/or fall in urine output
definitions_glossary.kdigo_criteria: International consensus definition for AKI diagnosis and staging
definitions_glossary.prerenal_azotemia: AKI from decreased renal perfusion with structurally normal kidneys
definitions_glossary.acute_tubular_necrosis: Intrinsic AKI from ischemic or toxic injury to renal tubular epithelial cells
definitions_glossary.postrenal_aki: AKI from obstruction of urinary outflow tract
definitions_glossary.fractional_excretion_sodium: FENa = (UNa × PCr)/(PNa × UCr) × 100; helps differentiate pre-renal from ATN
definitions_glossary.muddy_brown_casts: Urinary casts from degenerating tubular epithelial cells; pathognomonic for ATN
definitions_glossary.contrast_induced_nephropathy: AKI occurring 24-72 hours after iodinated contrast administration
definitions_glossary.hepatorenal_syndrome: Functional AKI in advanced liver disease from renal vasoconstriction
definitions_glossary.cardiorenal_syndrome: AKI in the setting of acute or chronic heart failure

pathophysiology.mechanism: Reduction in glomerular filtration rate (GFR) from hemodynamic changes, tubular injury, or obstruction
prerenal_causes: Decreased cardiac output (heart failure, cardiogenic shock)
Renal vasoconstriction (NSAIDs, ACE inhibitors/ARBs, contrast, hypercalcemia)
postrenal_causes: Bilateral ureteral obstruction (stones, tumor, retroperitoneal fibrosis)
Bladder outlet obstruction (BPH, prostate cancer, neurogenic bladder)

kdigo_staging.stage_1: Cr rise ≥0.3 mg/dL or 1.5-1.9× baseline; UOP <0.5 mL/kg/h for 6-12h
kdigo_staging.stage_3: Cr ≥3× baseline, or Cr ≥4 mg/dL, or initiation of RRT, or GFR <35 if <18yo; UOP <0.3 mL/kg/h for ≥24h or anuria ≥12h

urinalysis_findings.atn: Muddy brown granular casts, epithelial cell casts

diagnostic_workup.imaging: Renal ultrasound for all AKI (rule out obstruction, assess kidney size)

general_measures: Optimize hemodynamics (volume resuscitation if prerenal; diuresis if volume overloaded)

specific_treatment_by_type.prerenal: IV fluid resuscitation (crystalloid preferred); treat underlying cause (sepsis, heart failure)
specific_treatment_by_type.atn: Supportive care; no proven therapy to accelerate recovery; maintain euvolemia
specific_treatment_by_type.postrenal: Immediate bladder catheterization or ureteral stenting/nephrostomy; monitor for post-obstructive diuresis
specific_treatment_by_type.glomerulonephritis: Urgent nephrology consultation; may need immunosuppression
specific_treatment_by_type.ain: Discontinue offending drug; steroids may be considered

renal_replacement_therapy.indications: AEIOU - Acidosis (refractory), Electrolytes (hyperkalemia), Intoxication, Overload (volume), Uremia (encephalopathy, pericarditis)
renal_replacement_therapy.modalities: Intermittent hemodialysis (IHD), Continuous renal replacement therapy (CRRT), Peritoneal dialysis

skos.definition: Rapid decline in kidney function over hours to days characterized by rise in serum creatinine and/or decrease in urine output, staged using KDIGO criteria

subcodes: N17.0 - Acute kidney failure with tubular necrosis
N17.1 - Acute kidney failure with acute cortical necrosis

learning_objectives: Define AKI using KDIGO criteria (creatinine and urine output)
Classify AKI as pre-renal, intrinsic, or post-renal
Interpret FENa and urinalysis findings to determine AKI etiology
Recognize common nephrotoxins and preventable causes of AKI
Apply indications for renal replacement therapy (AEIOU)
Understand short and long-term outcomes of AKI
clinical_pearls: Creatinine lags behind actual GFR decline by 12-24 hours - early injury may be missed
FENa <1% suggests prerenal; >2% suggests ATN; use FEUrea if patient is on diuretics
Muddy brown casts on urinalysis are pathognomonic for ATN
Always get renal ultrasound to rule out obstruction - it's treatable
NSAIDs and ACE-I/ARB are the most common iatrogenic causes of AKI
AKI on CKD is very common - baseline creatinine is essential for staging
Post-obstructive diuresis can cause massive fluid/electrolyte losses - monitor closely
Even 'recovered' AKI increases long-term risk of CKD and cardiovascular events

common_questions: Patient with hypotension and Cr rise from 1.0 to 2.5, FENa 0.5% - type of AKI?
Muddy brown casts on UA - diagnosis?

Manage AKI based on underlying cause
clinical_pearls: KDIGO stages 1-3 based on creatinine and urine output
Always rule out obstruction with ultrasound
